explanation: The Heisenberg uncertainty principle states that the simultaneous precise measurement of position and momentum of a particle is fundamentally impossible. The product of their uncertainties has a quantum mechanical lower bound proportional to Planck's constant. This principle reflects the wave-particle duality and is a cornerstone of quantum mechanics, setting fundamental limits on measurement precision and enabling phenomena like quantum tunneling.

assumptions.text: The particle is described by a quantum mechanical wavefunction.
Position and momentum are represented by non-commuting Hermitian operators.
The uncertainties are defined as standard deviations of the observables.
The canonical commutation relation `[hat x, hat p] = i*hbar` holds for position and momentum operators.
The Cauchy-Schwarz inequality applies to quantum mechanical expectation values.

derivation_explanation.text: Start with the canonical commutation relation for position and momentum operators.
Define the variance (uncertainty squared) of an observable as the expectation value of the squared deviation from the mean.
Define shifted operators that have zero expectation value.
Express uncertainty in terms of shifted operators.
The commutation relation is preserved under this shift.
Apply the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality to the expectation value of the product of shifted operators.
Decompose the product into anticommutator and commutator parts.
The anticommutator part is real, the commutator part is imaginary.
For the inequality to be optimal, only the imaginary (commutator) part contributes.
Substitute the commutation relation and express in terms of uncertainties.
Take the square root to obtain the uncertainty relation.
